Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Collaborative Research: The Role of Brain Connectivity in Reasoning Development

Understanding the patterns of communication between brain regions, and how they develop across childhood, is critical for understanding the development of the neural mechanisms that implement complex cognitive operations such as reasoning. Functional connectivity, or correlations in patterns of brain activation (measured via fMRI), is thought to reflect this inter-regional communication. But communication between brain regions ultimately depends on structural connectivity: the white matter tracts that, either directly or indirectly, connect them. This proposal is aimed at resolving two open questions: 1) What are the dynamic relationships between structural and functional connectivity, for the key networks known to be involved in reasoning and other higher cognitive processes, as these develop together across childhood?, and 2) How do these dynamic relationships affect developmental improvements in reasoning ability? The answers that we obtain will provide both fundamental insight into the development of brain connectivity and mechanistic insight into the development of reasoning ability. This knowledge could impact future research both on educational and training programs designed to teach reasoning ability, and on interventions or medical programs designed to correct problems in reasoning.

To address these questions, we will combine fMRI, DTI, and behavioral data from three longitudinal developmental datasets, collected at UC Berkeley, UC Davis, and Vanderbilt University. By combining datasets, we are able to examine longitudinal data from 400 children and young adults between the ages of 6 and 22. Our primary measures of interest include a) intrinsic functional connectivity between specific regions of interest; b) structural connectivity, measured via fractional anisotropy along tracts that connect these regions; and c) reasoning ability, measured via standard cognitive tests. Our main analyses will focus on connectivity within and between two brain networks, the fronto-parietal network and cingulo-opercular network, which are most closely associated with reasoning and other higher cognitive functions. Mixed-model regression analyses will be employed to examine concurrent relationships among structural and functional connectivity in these networks and reasoning ability. Multivariate latent difference score models will be employed to examine lead-lag relationships. The outcome of this research will be a model of interacting structural and functional connectivity development across childhood, and of how the co-development of these two indicators of neural communication relates to developmental improvements in reasoning ability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The human capacity for reasoning develops substantially during childhood, and has a profound impact on achievement in school and in cognitively challenging careers. Research in adults has implicated several brain regions in reasoning ability ? most notably, specific subregions within lateral prefrontal and parietal cortices, including rostrolateral prefrontal cortex (RLPFC) and inferior parietal lobule (IPL).

Here, we sought to understand the brain mechanisms underlying developmental improvements ? and individual differences ? in reasoning over childhood and adolescence. Given that communication between prefrontal and parietal cortices (via the lateral fronto-parietal network) is thought to be essential for reasoning, and that long-range communication in the brain increases over development, we sought to test the hypothesis that changes in anatomical structure and/or functioning of the lateral fronto-parietal network would help to explain developmental changes and individual differences in reasoning ability. More specifically, we sought to test whether reasoning ability would be linked to anatomical and/or functional connectivity between RLPFC and IPL.

To test these hypotheses, we combined three large longitudinal developmental datasets with behavioral and neuroimaging data from 523 participants between 7 and 22 years old, scanned 1-3 times with intervals between testing sessions of approximately 1.5 years. This pooled dataset included diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) scans, functional MRI (fMRI) scans, and behavioral data. From the DTI scans, we used probabilistic tractography to identify the likely location of white matter tracts between these same pairs of regions, and then computed white matter coherence, considered a measure of strength of anatomical connections between regions (structural connectivity). From the fMRI scans, we calculated strength of the temporal coupling of activation between pairs of regions of interest (task-independent functional connectivity) in the lateral fronto-parietal network. We then tested whether structural and/or functional connectivity correlated with reasoning ability at a single timepoint (cross-sectional analyses) and/or predicted future reasoning ability (longitudinal analyses). 

Cross-sectionally, we found that reasoning was related to fronto-parietal (but not fronto-frontal or parieto-parietal) structural connectivity in children. By contrast, reasoning was related to functional connectivity between RLPFC and in adolescents and adults. Additionally, structural connectivity showed an earlier maturational trajectory than functional connectivity. We observed a positive, albeit weak, concurrent relationship between fronto-parietal structural and functional connectivity. Critically, we found that RLPFC-IPL structural connectivity at one time point positively predicted future changes in RLPFC-IPL functional connectivity; in contrast, functional connectivity did not predict future changes in structural connectivity. Finally, RLPFC-IPL structural connectivity, but not functional connectivity, was a positive predictor of future changes in reasoning ability.

Our results, published in the Journal of Neuroscience, demonstrate the importance of strong white matter connectivity between RLPFC and IPL during middle childhood for the subsequent development of both functional connectivity and reasoning ability. We have shown previously in research with adults that three months of intensive practicing of reasoning skills alters structural and functional connectivity in the lateral fronto-parietal cortex. However, the results from this grant raise the possibility that opportunities to hone reasoning skills will be most impactful if they take place by mid-childhood, while the white matter connections are undergoing more pronounced structural changes.

This grant focused on reasoning development; however, the combined longitudinal dataset includes numerous variables that can be used to test other questions. Indeed, we have used subsets of the data to examine other aspects of child development; some of these investigations have been written up for publication, and others are underway. We have also shared the dataset with numerous other labs.
